title: 107_hr3199
content: The "Significant Regulation Oversight Act of 2001" requires significant rules proposed by agencies to undergo congressional review and approval before taking effect. Congress aims to ensure that these rules align with the intent of the enacted law and are approved through established procedures. The "Significant Regulation Oversight Act of 2001" mandates that significant rules must receive congressional approval through a joint resolution before becoming effective. Agencies proposing significant rules must submit a report to Congress including the rule, a summary, cost-benefit analysis, and statutory interpretation explanation. The "Significant Regulation Oversight Act of 2001" requires agencies to submit a report to Congress when proposing significant rules. The report must include the rule, a summary, cost-benefit analysis, statutory interpretation explanation, and any other relevant information or requirements under other Acts and Executive orders. Upon receipt of the report, each House of Congress must provide a copy to the Chairman and ranking minority party member of each relevant committee. The "Significant Regulation Oversight Act of 2001" mandates agencies to submit a report to Congress for proposed significant rules. If Congress does not approve a rule, no inference can be drawn from Congress's actions or inactions regarding the rule or related statutes. Congressional approval procedure for significant rules is outlined in SEC. 4. The majority leader of each House of Congress must introduce a joint resolution containing the text of a proposed significant rule within 3 session days in the Senate or 3 legislative days in the House of Representatives after the agency submits a report. The joint resolution is referred to the appropriate committee for consideration, which may report it without revision, with or without recommendation, or with an adverse recommendation. The joint resolution must be reported by the committee within 45 session days in the Senate or 45 legislative days in the House. If not reported, the committee is automatically discharged. A vote on final passage must occur within 90 session days in the Senate or 90 legislative days in the House after introduction. The House of Representatives has specific rules for considering joint resolutions, including limited debate time and restrictions on amendments and motions. Appeals related to the application of House rules can be made to the chair. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to joint resolutions without debate. In the Senate, a motion to consider a joint resolution is privileged and not debatable, with limited debate time of 10 hours. Amendments to the motion are not allowed. In the Senate, debate on a joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Debate on motions or appeals is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and manager, with additional time allotted by leaders. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable. Under this section, a joint resolution is not debatable and cannot be recommitted. No amendments are allowed in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. If the other House has passed a joint resolution with the same text, the procedure remains the same. The joint resolution process outlined in this section is non-debatable and cannot be amended or recommitted. The final vote on the resolution will be based on the version passed by the other House. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, superseding other rules only if inconsistent. Each House retains the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures. SEC. 5. EXISTING RULES. Any existing rule may be revised or revoked if a petition for review is filed and meets certain requirements. The majority leader must introduce a joint resolution within a specified timeframe to enact the proposed changes. If not introduced, any Member of that House may do so. Any joint resolution introduced under subsection (b) shall be considered in the House of Representatives and the Senate in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 4. A petition for review under subsection (a) must contain the affected rule and its contents, along with signatures from 30 Senators or 120 Members depending on the House. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "session day," "legislative day," and "rule," with specific exclusions for the term "rule." The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "session day," "legislative day," and "rule," with specific exclusions for the term "rule." A "significant rule" refers to any rule proposed by an agency specified in the Act. A "final rule" encompasses any final or interim rule related to corporate structures, reorganizations, mergers, acquisitions, accounting practices, disclosures, agency organization, personnel, procedures, practices, or routine matters. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION FOR MONETARY POLICY. This Act does not apply to any rule regarding monetary policy proposed or implemented by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or the Federal Open Market Committee.
